title: Marion Bailey
text:
Marion Bailey (born 5 May 1951) is an English actress. She is best known for her work with her partner, filmmaker <a href="Mike%20Leigh">Mike Leigh</a>, including the films "<a href="Meantime%20%28film%29">Meantime</a>" (1983), "<a href="All%20or%20Nothing%20%28film%29">All or Nothing</a>" (2002), "<a href="Vera%20Drake">Vera Drake</a>" (2004), "<a href="Mr.%20Turner">Mr. Turner</a>" (2014), for which she was nominated Supporting Actress of the Year by the <a href="London%20Film%20Critics%27%20Circle">London Film Critics' Circle</a>, and most recently "<a href="Peterloo%20%28film%29">Peterloo</a>" (2018). More recently, in 2019 and 2020, she has portrayed <a href="Queen%20Elizabeth%20The%20Queen%20Mother">Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother</a> in the <a href="The%20Crown%20%28season%203%29">third</a> and <a href="The%20Crown%20%28season%204%29">fourth seasons</a> of "<a href="The%20Crown%20%28TV%20series%29">The Crown</a>" on <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a>.
Personal life.
Bailey was born in Bushey Hospital, in <a href="Bushey">Bushey</a>, <a href="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>, to Rose (née Timberlake) and William Bailey. She grew up in <a href="Harrow%2C%20London">Harrow</a>, Middlesex, and attended <a href="Pinner%20County%20Grammar%20School">Pinner County Grammar School</a>. She was a member of the National Youth Theatre of Great Britain and trained at the <a href="Guildhall%20School%20of%20Music%20and%20Drama">Guildhall School of Music and Drama</a>.
Film career.
As well as Leigh's films, Bailey has appeared as Mrs Peach in <a href="Debbie%20Isitt">Debbie Isitt</a>'s "Nasty Neighbours" (2000), Mary in the <a href="Craig%20Ferguson">Craig Ferguson</a> film "<a href="I%27ll%20Be%20There%20%282003%20film%29">I'll Be There</a>" and Mrs Adams in S.J.Clarkson's "Toast" (2010). Bailey starred as Mrs Booth in "<a href="Mr.%20Turner">Mr. Turner</a>" (2014) and appeared in "<a href="The%20Lady%20in%20the%20Van">The Lady in the Van</a>" (2015), "<a href="Allied%20%28film%29">Allied</a>" (2016), "<a href="Dead%20In%20A%20Week%20%28or%20your%20money%20back%29">Dead In A Week (or your money back)</a>" (2018), <a href="Elizabeth%20Conyngham%2C%20Marchioness%20Conyngham">Lady Conyngham</a> in Leigh’s "<a href="Peterloo%20%28film%29">Peterloo</a>" (2018) and played Dinah in Stephen Cookson's "Brighton"(2019).
Television career.
Bailey's television work includes "<a href="Inspector%20Morse%20%28TV%20series%29">Inspector Morse</a>", "<a href="Casualty%20%28TV%20series%29">Casualty</a>", "<a href="The%20Bill">The Bill</a>", "<a href="Holby%20City">Holby City</a>", "<a href="Midsomer%20Murders">Midsomer Murders</a>", "<a href="Agatha%20Christie%27s%20Poirot">Agatha Christie's Poirot</a>", "<a href="A%20Touch%20of%20Frost">A Touch of Frost</a>", "<a href="Dalziel%20and%20Pascoe%20%28TV%20series%29">Dalziel and Pascoe</a>", "<a href="Big%20Deal%20%28TV%20series%29">Big Deal</a>", "<a href="Boon%20%28TV%20series%29">Boon</a>", "The Bretts", "<a href="The%20Ruth%20Rendell%20Mysteries">The Ruth Rendell Mysteries</a>", "<a href="No%20More%20Dying%20Then">No More Dying Then</a>", "<a href="Stay%20Lucky">Stay Lucky</a>", "<a href="Heat%20of%20the%20Sun">Heat of the Sun</a>", "<a href="Micawber%20%28TV%20series%29">Micawber</a>", <a href="New%20Tricks">New Tricks</a>, "<a href="Monday%20Monday">Monday Monday</a>, <a href="Being%20Human%20%28UK%20TV%20series%29">Being Human</a>" and "<a href="Case%20Histories%20%28TV%20series%29">Case Histories</a>". In 1995, she had a recurring role as Avis in the long-running ITV series "<a href="Shine%20on%20Harvey%20Moon">Shine on Harvey Moon</a>". She also played leading roles in several popular 1980s TV series, including "<a href="To%20Have%20%26amp%3B%20to%20Hold%20%28American%20TV%20series%29">To Have and to Hold</a>", "Jury" and "Charlie".
In 2000, she played Wendy in Carlton's comedy drama series "The Thing About Vince". She has also appeared in many single TV dramas and films including "Woyzeck", "Way Upstream", "Zackharov", "Raspberry", "Coppers", Derailed, "Toast" and <a href="Jane%20Austen">Jane Austen</a>'s "<a href="Persuasion%20%282007%20film%29">Persuasion</a>". She played Jill in the <a href="BBC%20Three">BBC Three</a> comedy series Him and Her, Sue in "<a href="The%20Trials%20of%20Jimmy%20Rose">The Trials of Jimmy Rose</a> and most recently Ingrid in Temple and Cara in Britannia for Sky." She played <a href="Queen%20Elizabeth%20The%20Queen%20Mother">Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother</a> in seasons 3 and 4 of international Netflix series "<a href="The%20Crown%20%28TV%20series%29">The Crown</a>", for which she was the recipient of a Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Television Drama Series.
Theatre career.
Bailey has worked extensively in British theatre, including at the <a href="Chichester%20Festival%20Theatre">Chichester</a> and the <a href="Hampstead%20Theatre">Hampstead Theatre</a>, and at the <a href="Bristol%20Old%20Vic">Bristol Old Vic</a>, the <a href="West%20Yorkshire%20Playhouse">West Yorkshire Playhouse</a>, London's West End, the <a href="Royal%20Court%20Theatre">Royal Court</a>, the <a href="Royal%20National%20Theatre">National Theatre</a>, <a href="the%20Old%20Vic">the Old Vic</a>, the <a href="Arts%20Theatre">Arts Theatre</a> and the <a href="Tricycle%20Theatre">Tricycle Theatre</a>. In 1981 she performed in Mike Leigh's <a href="West%20End%20theatre">West End</a> theatre play "Goosepimples", for which she received a Plays and Players Award nomination as Most Promising Newcomer. In 2007, with the <a href="Shared%20Experience">Shared Experience</a> company she received a <a href="Theatrical%20Management%20Association">TMA</a> nomination as Best Supporting Performance for her role in "<a href="Kindertransport">Kindertransport</a>".
Bailey appeared in Mike Leigh's "Grief" at the <a href="Royal%20National%20Theatre">National Theatre</a> (2011/12). In 2013 she played the Queen in "<a href="Handbagged">Handbagged</a>" at the <a href="Tricycle%20Theatre">Tricycle Theatre</a> and in the production's subsequent <a href="West%20End%20theatre">West End</a> transfer to the <a href="Vaudeville%20Theatre">Vaudeville Theatre</a>. She returned to the National Theatre to appear in Carrie Cracknell's productions "Blurred Lines" (2015) and "The Deep Blue Sea" (2016).
